qas.question: What did the indigenous peoples of America cultivate over the course of thousands of years?

answers.text: a large array of plant species

qas.question: What percent of worldwide crops in cultivation derive from the efforts of the America's indigenous people?
How were new species and strains of crops developed?
What was the origin of maize?
What products sometimes retain their native names in both English and Spanish?

context: Over the course of thousands of years, American indigenous peoples domesticated, bred and cultivated <a0_0>a large array of plant species<a0_0/>. These species now constitute <a1_0>50–60%<a1_0/> of all crops in cultivation worldwide. In certain cases, the indigenous peoples developed entirely new species and strains through <a2_0>artificial selection<a2_0/>, as was the case in the domestication and breeding of maize from <a3_0>wild teosinte grasses<a3_0/> in the valleys of southern Mexico. Numerous such <a4_0>agricultural<a4_0/> products retain their native names in the English and Spanish lexicons.
